questions.question: Which cerebellar zone is mainly associated with processing proprioceptive information?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Paleocerebellum Explanation: The paleocerebellum is responsible for processing proprioceptive information obtained from the spinal cord. It plays a vital role in coordinating limb movements and maintaining body posture through feedback from muscle and joint receptors. Comprises the anterior lobe (excluding the lingula) and parts of the posterior lobe, particularly the pyramid and uvula of the inferior vermis. Archicerebellum (Option A): This zone is primarily linked to the vestibular system, which focuses on balance and posture rather than proprioceptive input from the body. The nodules (lobule X) and lingula (lobule I) are part of the archicerebellum. Neocerebellum (Option C): Its function is integrating sensory information from the cerebral cortex for higher-level motor planning. Mainly consists of the posterior lobe, particularly the large cerebellar hemispheres, excluding the pyramid and uvula. Vestibulocerebellum (Option D): This term refers to the archicerebellum, which is more focused on balance and eye movement rather than proprioception

questions.question: Which pathway involves inhibitory projections originating from the cerebellar nuclei, contributing to the regulation of motor activity and coordination?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Nucleo-olivary pathway Explanation: The nucleo-olivary pathway sends inhibitory projections from the cerebellar nuclei , particularly regulating motor activity and coordination. This pathway helps in adjusting cerebellar output to maintain smooth, coordinated movement. Cerebellar Output Excitatory Cerebellar nuclei to Brainstem nuclei (via Glutamate) Inhibitory Purkinjee cells to Cerebellum (via GABA) Cerebellar Nuclei to Inferior Olive: Nucleo-Olivary Pathway (via GABA) Rubrospinal tract (Option A): The rubrospinal tract transmits signals from the red nucleus to the spinal cord, primarily assisting in controlling limb movements. While influenced by cerebellar output, it does not carry inhibitory projections from the cerebellar nuclei. Ventral spinocerebellar tract (Option C): This tract transmits proprioceptive signals to the cerebellum, mainly providing feedback from spinal interneurons. However, it does not carry inhibitory projections from the cerebellar nuclei. Vestibulospinal tract (Option D): This pathway sends excitatory signals from the vestibular nuclei to the spinal cord, helping in balance and posture control. It is not related to the cerebellar inhibitory pathways.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about cerebellar circuitry is false?

options.A: Climbing fibres directly excite Purkinje cells by forming extensive synaptic connections.
options.B: Mossy fibres excite Purkinje cells through granule cells, creating a diffuse excitatory effect.
options.C: Purkinje cells send excitatory signals to deep cerebellar nuclei.
options.D: Stellate, basket, and Golgi cells serve as inhibitory interneurons in the cerebellar cortex.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Purkinje cells send excitatory signals to deep cerebellar nuclei. Explanation: Purkinje cells send inhibitory signals, not excitatory, to deep cerebellar nuclei. The cerebellar cortex contains five types of intrinsic neurons: Purkinje cells, granule cells, stellate cells, basket cells, and Golgi cells. All are inhibitory except for granule cells, making this unique arrangement of inhibitory neurons exclusive to the cerebellum in the central nervous system Cerebellum Circuit The cerebellar circuitry operates with a balance between excitatory and inhibitory inputs. Climbing fibres (from olivocerebellar tracts) excite Purkinje cells by forming extensive synapses with their dendrites. One climbing fibre connects with multiple Purkinje cells. (Option A ruled out) Mossy fibres (from other cerebellar tracts) excite thousands of Purkinje cells indirectly via granule cells , creating a more diffuse excitatory effect. (Option B ruled out) The stellate, basket and Golgi cells serve as inhibitory interneurons within the cerebellar cortex, controlling the spread and intensity of excitation in Purkinje cells. (Option D ruled out) This inhibition refines and modulates the excitatory input from both the climbing and mossy fibres, ensuring precise motor coordination. Purkinje cells send inhibitory signals to deep cerebellar nuclei (Output centres), which integrate both excitatory inputs from climbing and mossy fibres and inhibitory input from Purkinje cells. This combination of inputs allows the cerebellum to finely tune motor commands before transmitting them to other regions of the brain and spinal cord. Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter used by climbing and mossy fibres to activate Purkinje cells. Norepinephrine and serotonin , modulate this excitatory action, influencing the overall effect on the cerebellar cortex. Finally, the cerebellum communicates with the rest of the central nervous system through three peduncles: Superior cerebellar peduncles link to the midbrain. Middle cerebellar peduncles connect to the pons. Inferior cerebellar peduncles connect to the medulla. Through these pathways, the cerebellum integrates sensory information and helps coordinate motor output essential for smooth, coordinated movements.

questions.question: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe vertigo, bilateral hearing loss, and tinnitus. He also exhibits facial weakness on the right side and demonstrates ataxia when attempting to walk. An MRI performed to evaluate the condition is given below. Which artery is most likely affected in this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Anterior inferior cerebellar artery Explanation: The symptoms—severe vertigo, bilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and facial weakness—are indicative of an AICA stroke. The MRI image shows a B/L infarct in the anterior cerebellum, which further confirms the involvement of AICA. The AICA arises from the caudal third of the basilar artery and supplies the inner ear, lateral pons, and the anterior inferior cerebellum. Diffusion-weighted MRI shows B/L infarct in the anterior cerebellum The anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) generally arises from the caudal third of the basilar artery and supplies the following areas: Inner ear

questions.question: Which type of fibres enter the cerebellum via the middle cerebellar peduncle?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cerebro-ponto-cerebellar fibres Explanation: Cerebro-ponto-cerebellar fibres, a part of mossy fibres, originate from the cerebral cortex, synapse in the pons, and then project to the cerebellum via the middle cerebellar peduncle , playing a key role in coordinating movement and processing sensory information. They have excitatory terminals on granule cells , which excite Purkinje cells. Climbing fibres, on the other hand, enter via the inferior cerebellar peduncle and target Purkinje cells directly. Afferent fibres Tract Enter Cerebellum Via Target and Function Climbing fibres Olivo-cerebellar (Option A ruled out) Inferior cerebellar peduncle (decussates) Excitatory terminals on Purkinje cells (glutamate) Mossy fibres Cerebro-ponto- cerebellar (Option B) Middle cerebellar peduncle (decussates) Excitatory terminals on granule cells (glutamate), which are excitatory to Purkinje cells Spinocerebellar (Option C ruled out) Inferior cerebellar peduncle Superior cerebellar peduncle Vestibulo-cerebellar (Option D ruled out) Inferior cerebellar peduncle Reference: Snell’s Clinical Neuroanatomy, 8th edition, Pages 234- 237

questions.question: Which of the following structures receives direct projections from the dentate nucleus?

options.C: The anterior nucleus of the thalamus

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Ventrolateral nucleus of the thalamus Explanation: The ventrolateral nucleus of the thalamus is the primary structure receiving direct projections from the dentate nucleus via the superior cerebellar peduncle. This pathway is crucial for motor control and coordination. Premotor cortex (Option A): The premotor cortex is involved in planning and organising movements but does not receive direct projections from the dentate nucleus. Information reaches the premotor cortex indirectly through the thalamus. The anterior nucleus of the thalamus (Option C): The anterior nucleus of the thalamus primarily relays information related to limbic functions and is not a target for direct projections from the dentate nucleus. Parietal cortex (Option D): The parietal cortex is involved in sensory processing and higher cognitive functions. While it receives input from the thalamus, it does not receive direct projections from the dentate nucleus. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Pages 468, 484.e1 Vishram Singh Anatomy of head, neck and brain, Volume 3, 2nd Edition, Page 354, 369, 378, 392

questions.question: The fastigial nucleus primarily projects to which of the following structures?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Vestibular nuclei Explanation: The vestibular nuclei receive major projections from the fastigial nucleus , playing a key role in maintaining balance, regulating posture, and coordinating head and eye movements via the vestibulospinal tracts. Connections of Cerebellum Part of cerebellum Cerebellar Nuclei Centre Neocerebellum Dentate Red Nucleus and Thalamus (Option B ruled out) Paleocerebellum Globose and Emobliform Red Nucleus (Option A ruled out) Archicerebellum Fastigial Vestibular Nuclei (Option C) Cerebral cortex (Option D): The cerebral cortex is influenced indirectly by cerebellar nuclei, especially via the thalamus. However, the fastigial nucleus does not send direct projections to the cortex.

questions.question: Which of the following intrinsic neurons are correctly matched with their respective layers in the cerebellar cortex?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) 3- Granular layer; Golgi cells Explanation: Golgi cells are found in the granular layer of the cerebellar cortex. They are inhibitory interneurons that play a role in modulating the activity of granule cells. The cerebellar cortex consists of the following three distinct layers: Layers of the cerebellar cortex Molecular (plexiform) layer (Option C ruled out) Purkinje cell layer (Option B ruled out) Granular layer (Option A ruled out) It primarily contains numerous dendritic branches from Purkinje cells, with relatively few widely spaced nerve cells. It consists of a single row of large flask-shaped cells, the Purkinje cells . The inner granular layer is made up of many closely packed small granule cells , along with a few larger Golgi cells. These nerve cells are of two types: (a) Basket cells (b) Stellate cells. The axons of Purkinje cells are the only output from the cerebellar cortex and have an inhibitory effect on the intracerebellar nuclei. Golgi cells are inhibitory while the granular cells are excitatory. Among the five types of intrinsic neurons (Basket cells, Stellate cells, Purkinje cells, Granule cells and Golgi cells)- All are inhibitory except granule cells.

questions.question: Which of the following deep cerebellar nuclei is primarily involved in the smooth execution of skilled voluntary movements?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Dentate nucleus Explanation: The deep cerebellar nuclei are clusters of grey matter situated within the white matter of the cerebellum. These nuclei are critical hubs for processing and relaying information related to motor control and coordination. Deep Cerebellar nuclei Dentate Nucleus (Option D) Emboliform Nucleus Globose Nucleus Fastigial Nucleus Largest and most lateral. Receives input from the neocerebellum. Involved in coordinating skilled, voluntary movements, especially of the limbs. Efferent fibres exit through the superior cerebellar peduncle . Oval-shaped, medial to the dentate nucleus. The emboliform nucleus combined with the globose nucleus is called Nucleus Interposus. Receives input from the paleocerebellum. Plays a role in general motor coordination. (Option B ruled out) Rounded, positioned between the emboliform and fastigial nuclei. Also part of the paleocerebellum. Works together with the emboliform nucleus for motor control. (Option C ruled out) Most medial, near the midline. Receives input from the archicerebellum , specifically the flocculonodular lobe. Important for balance, posture, and coordinating head and eye movements. (Option A ruled out) Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Pages 465, 468, 481, 483, 484 Netter Atlas of Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Plate 142, Page 199 Vishram Singh Anatomy of head, neck and brain, Volume 3, 2nd Edition, Page 376, 377, 378

questions.question: What is the significance of the second decussation of the ventral spinocerebellar tract within the cerebellum?

options.D: Causes all fibres to terminate bilaterally

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Ensures ipsilateral proprioceptive termination. Explanation: The second crossing within the cerebellum ensures that the proprioceptive signals from one side of the body ultimately terminate on the same side of the cerebellum , aiding in precise coordination of movement. Ventral Spinocerebellar Tract Pathway Begins in the lumbar and sacral spinal cord (intermediate grey matter and dorsal horn base). ↓ Fibers cross the midline in the spinal cord via the ventral white commissure. ↓ The tract ascends through the spinal cord and brainstem, running near the spinothalamic tract. ↓ Enters the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle at the level of the midbrain. ↓ Fibres recross within the cerebellum’s white matter. ↓ The majority of fibres end in the anterior cerebellar vermis, with a smaller portion terminating bilaterally. Enables contralateral proprioceptive processing (Option A): The second decussation does not lead to contralateral processing but instead causes the proprioceptive signals to be processed on the same side (ipsilateral) as their origin. Blocks incorrect proprioceptive signals (Option C): The second decussation does not prevent signal transmission but ensures that signals from the body are processed correctly by the cerebellum after crossing back to the original side. Causes all fibres to terminate bilaterally (Option D): Only about 15% of fibres may terminate bilaterally, the main role of the second decussation is not to cause bilateral termination but to direct most fibres to terminate ipsilaterally. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Pages 431, 448

questions.question: From which anatomical structure does the dorsal spinocerebellar tract originate?

options.A: Anterior horn of the spinal cord

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Posterior thoracic nucleus (Clarke's column) Explanation: The dorsal spinocerebellar tract originates from neurons located in the Posterior thoracic nucleus (Clarke's column) nucleus, situated in the thoracic and upper lumbar regions of the spinal cord. It enters the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle and terminates in the ipsilateral cerebellar cortex. These neurons process input from proprioceptive receptors, such as muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs. It carries unconscious proprioception. Tracts of the spinal cord Anterior horn of the spinal cord (Option A): This region mainly contains motor neurons responsible for transmitting signals to skeletal muscles. It does not give rise to the dorsal spinocerebellar tract, which is primarily involved in sensory processing. Cerebellar cortex (Option B): This area is the termination for the dorsal spinocerebellar tract fibres, where proprioceptive information is integrated for coordination and balance, rather than being the site of origin for the tract itself. Medulla oblongata (Option C): This structure is part of the brainstem and plays a role in autonomic functions and motor control. However, it does not serve as the origin point for the dorsal spinocerebellar tract. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Pages 431, 445, 477 Netter Atlas of Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Plate 40, Page 305 Vishram Singh Anatomy of head, neck and brain, Volume 3, 2nd Edition, Page 306, 310, 311, 356

questions.question: Which cerebellar peduncle is primarily composed of only afferent fibres?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Middle cerebellar peduncle Explanation: The middle cerebellar peduncle is composed exclusively of afferent fibres originating from the contralateral pontine nuclei. It plays a crucial role in relaying information from various areas of the cerebral cortex to the cerebellum, facilitating the coordination of movement and motor planning. Cerebellar Peduncles Afferent Efferent Superior cerebellar peduncle Ventral Spinocerebellar Tract All efferent fibres from dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose nuclei (Option C ruled out) Middle cerebellar peduncle Pontocerebellar Mossy Fibre Pathway No efferent fibres (Option A) Inferior cerebellar peduncle Dorsal Spinocerebellar Tract Olivocerebellar Tract Reticulocerebellar Tract Few efferents from the cerebellum to the medulla oblongata, mainly to vestibular nuclei and reticular formation. (Option A ruled out) All of the above (Option D): Incorrect, as the only peduncle that consists solely of afferent fibres is the middle cerebellar peduncle. The others include both afferent and efferent fibres. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Pages 445, 467, 468 Netter Atlas of Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Plate 141, Page 198 Vishram Singh Anatomy of head, neck and brain, Volume 3, 2nd Edition, Page 378

questions.question: Which cerebellar lobe is associated with maintaining balance and controlling eye movements?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Flocculonodular Lobe Explanation: The Flocculonodular Lobe, also known as the vestibulocerebellum, has direct and strong connections to the vestibular system, which governs balance, posture, and eye movements. The flocculonodular lobe helps coordinate head, neck, and eye movements based on vestibular input, which is crucial for maintaining equilibrium. Cerebellum The anterior lobe (Option B): Found on the superior surface of the cerebellum, this lobe plays a key role in motor coordination, through its connections to the spinocerebellar tracts that transmit sensory information from the spinal cord. The posterior lobe (Option C) is involved in motor planning and higher cognitive functions. Its connections with association areas of the cerebral cortex, such as the prefrontal and parietal regions, allow it to contribute to the coordination of complex movements rather than balance. Neocerebellum (Option D): Referring primarily to the posterior lobe, the neocerebellum is involved in regulating complex movements and processing higher cognitive functions.

questions.question: Identify the correct option.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 5- Abducens nerve; 3- Vagus nerve Explanation: Attachment of the nerves to the brain: 1, 2 - Forebrain 3- Arises from ventral midbrain 4- Dorsal midbrain (cannot see its origin in the Anterior view of the brainstem) 5- Lateral pons 6, 7, 8- Ponto medullary junction (from medial to lateral respectively) 9, 10, 11- Lateral to olives (from superior to inferior respectively) 12- Between pyramid and olives

questions.question: Match the following neural columns with their corresponding cranial nerve nuclei. 1. General Somatic Efferent (GSE) A) Nucleus ambiguus 2. Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) B) Edinger-Westphal nucleus 3. General Visceral Efferent (GVE) C) Oculomotor nucleus 4. Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) D) Nucleus of the solitary tract
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A Explanation: 1. General Somatic Efferent (GSE) The GSE column controls muscles derived from somites, specifically the striated muscles. C) Oculomotor nucleus In the brainstem, it is represented by nuclei like the oculomotor nucleus , which innervates the extraocular muscles, facilitating eye movement. 2. Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) The SVA column is responsible for processing special sensory information related to taste. D) Nucleus of the solitary tract In the brainstem, the nucleus of the solitary tract receives taste signals from the tongue, transmitted by cranial nerves like the facial and glossopharyngeal nerves. 3. General Visceral Efferent (GVE) The GVE column regulates autonomic functions, particularly parasympathetic innervation. B) Edinger-Westphal nucleus The Edinger-Westphal nucleus in the midbrain is part of this system, controlling pupil constriction and lens accommodation. 4. Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) The SVE column innervates muscles derived from the branchial arches, responsible for functions like swallowing and speech. A) Nucleus ambiguus The nucleus ambiguus provides motor innervation to muscles involved in these actions, via cranial nerves like the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Page 391 Vishram Singh Anatomy of head, neck and brain, Volume 3, 2nd Edition, Page 372

questions.question: Which of the following correctly arranges the brainstem nuclei from medial to lateral in the brainstem? → Trochlear nucleus → Edinger Westphal nucleus → Dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus → Nucleus tractus solitarius → Motor nuclei of Facial → Abducent nucleus → Hypoglossal nucleus → Nucleus tractus solitarius
questions.explanation: → Dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus → Nucleus tractus solitarius → Dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus → Nucleus tractus solitarius Oculomotor nucleus → Trochlear nucleus → Edinger Westphal nucleus (Option A): Edinger Westphal lies dorsal to the oculomotor nucleus and not lateral. Motor nuclei of Trigeminal → Motor nuclei of Facial → Abducent nucleus (Option C): The motor nucleus of the facial nerve lies ventrolateral to the abducent nucleus. Nucleus ambiguus → Hypoglossal nucleus → Nucleus tractus solitarius (Option D): Hypoglossal nuclei are medial to Nucleus Ambiguus. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Pages 444, 453, 458 Snell’s Clinical Neuroanatomy, 8th Edition, Page 203 Nuclei, Functional Components .

questions.question: Which nuclei belong to the Special Somatic Afferent (SSA) column?

options.B: Sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Cochlear and vestibular nuclei Explanation: Cochlear and vestibular nuclei are part of the SSA column, carrying special senses of hearing and balance. Neural column Nuclei and Cranial Nerves GSE (General Somatic Efferent) (Option C ruled out) SVE (Special Visceral Efferent) (Option D ruled out) GVE (General Visceral Efferent) GVA/SVA (General/Special Visceral Efferent) GSA (General Somatic Afferent) (Option B ruled out) SSA (Special Somatic Afferent) (Option A) Oculomotor nucleus (III) Trochlear nucleus (IV) Abducent nucleus (VI) Hypoglossal nucleus (XII) Motor nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve (V) Motor nucleus of the facial nerve (VII) Nucleus ambiguus (IX, X, XI) Edinger Westphal nucleus (III) Superior salivatory nucleus (VII) Inferior salivatory nucleus (IX) Dorsal nucleus of Vagus (X) Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (GVA - IX, X) (SVA - VII, IX) Sensory nuclei of Trigeminal Nerve (V, IX, X) Vestibular nuclei (VIII) Cochlear nuclei (VIII) The lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus (II). Olfactory bulb (I) Mnemonic: Rule of 12: Any nucleus that is inclusive of 12 is medial. It includes nuclei III, IV, VI and XII. The rest are lateral. Rule of M: 3 primary medial tracts of the Brainstem. Includes Motor Tract (Corticospinal Tract), Medial Lemniscus and Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus. Rule of S: Lateral or “side” tracts. Includes Spinothalamic tract, Sympathetic tract and spinocerebellar tracts. B- Branchial Motor, CST-Corticospinal, STT- Spinothalamic, ML- Medial Lemniscus, Sm- Somatic motor, Sp-Special sensory, Ss- Somatic sensory Section through medulla showing arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei

questions.question: Which artery is most commonly occluded, leading to medial medullary syndrome and lateral pontine syndrome, respectively?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Anterior spinal artery, AICA Explanation: Anterior Spinal Artery: Its occlusion leads to medial medullary syndrome, resulting in contralateral hemiplegia, loss of vibration and position sense, and tongue paralysis on the same side. AICA (Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery): Occlusion leads to lateral pontine syndrome, causing symptoms like facial paralysis, vertigo, nystagmus, and ataxia. Medial Medullary Syndrome (Dejerine Syndrome) Cause: Occlusion of the anterior spinal artery Features: Contralateral Hemiplegia: Due to damage to the medullary pyramid. Loss of Vibration and Position Sense: Resulting from damage to the medial lemniscus. Tongue Paralysis (Same Side): Caused by injury to the hypoglossal (XII) cranial nerve. Lateral Inferior Pontine Syndrome Cause: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) On Side of Lesion: Nystagmus, Vertigo, Nausea, Vomiting, Oscillopsia: Due to vestibular nerve/nucleus involvement. Facial Paralysis Impaired Conjugate Gaze: Involvement of the center for lateral gaze. Deafness and Tinnitus: Related to the auditory nerve or cochlear nucleus. Ataxia: Affecting the middle cerebellar peduncle and cerebellar hemisphere. Impaired Sensation Over Face: Due to involvement of the descending tract and nucleus of the fifth nerve. On Side Opposite Lesion: Impaired Pain and Thermal Sensation: Involving the spinothalamic tract over one-half of the body, which may include the face. Anterior cerebral artery, PICA (Option A): Anterior Cerebral Artery: Occlusion affects the medial frontal and parietal lobes, causing contralateral leg weakness and sensory loss, but does not cause the medial medullary syndrome. PICA: Occlusion leads to lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome), not lateral pontine syndrome. Posterior cerebral artery, Basilar artery (Option B): Posterior Cerebral Artery: Occlusion affects the occipital lobe, causing visual field deficits and sensory disturbances, but not medial medullary syndrome. Basilar Artery: Occlusion leads to various brainstem syndromes, but is not specifically linked to lateral pontine syndrome. Vertebral artery, Superior cerebellar artery (Option D): Vertebral Artery: Occlusion affects posterior circulation, causing various syndromes, but not medial medullary syndrome. Superior Cerebellar Artery: Occlusion primarily impacts the cerebellum and brainstem, but does not cause lateral pontine syndrome.

questions.question: Which arteries supply the posterior region of the superior medulla and pons respectively?

options.A: Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery and Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery
options.C: Anterior Spinal Artery and Posterior Spinal Artery
options.D: Superior Cerebellar Artery and Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery and Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (Option C ruled out) Posterior-Lateral Supply: Posterior Spinal Artery Superiorly Lateral Supply: Vertebral Artery (Option B ruled out) Anterior Supply: Basilar Artery branches Posterior Supply: Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) Blood supply of Pons: Main Supply: Pontine branches of the Basilar Artery Posterior-Lateral Supply: Branches of the Superior Cerebellar Artery (Option D ruled out) and the Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA)

questions.question: Which artery supplies the posterior region of the midbrain?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Superior Cerebellar Artery Explanation: Superior Cerebellar Artery provides significant blood supply to the posterior region of the midbrain Midbrain Blood Supply: Anterior-Medial Supply: branches of the Basilar artery (Option A ruled out) Anterior-Lateral Supply: branches of the Posterior Choroidal arteries and Quadrigeminal artery from the Posterior Cerebral Artery (Option B & C ruled out) Posterior Supply: Quadrigeminal Artery and Superior Cerebellar Artery Reference: Neuroanatomy, Brainstem - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf The Midbrain - Colliculi - Peduncles - TeachMeAnatomy

questions.question: The baroreceptor reflex that helps regulate blood pressure involves general visceral afferent (GVA) fibres from which of the following receptors and pathways?

options.A: Carotid body via the glossopharyngeal nerve
options.B: Aortic bodies via the vagus nerve
options.C: Carotid sinus via the vagus nerve
options.D: Pulmonary arteries via the glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Aortic bodies via the vagus nerve Explanation: The aortic bodies detect changes in blood pressure and relay sensory input through GVA fibres of the vagus nerve, contributing to the baroreceptor reflex. Baroreceptor Reflex: Baroreceptors in the aortic arch and carotid sinus monitor blood pressure changes. GVA fibres from the aortic arch transmit signals via the vagus nerve (X), and from the carotid sinus via the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX). The brainstem's nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) receives signals from GVA fibres. GVE fibres originating from the vagus nerve (X) from the dorsal motor nucleus mediate parasympathetic responses. They adjust heart rate by influencing the sinoatrial (SA) node, AV node, myocardium and other cardiac structures, helping to lower blood pressure when necessary. Carotid body via the glossopharyngeal nerve (Option A): Carotid body detects gases, not pressure; the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) relates to baroreceptors in the carotid sinus. Carotid sinus via the vagus nerve (Option C): While the carotid sinus does detect blood pressure changes, it transmits signals via the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), not the vagus nerve. Pulmonary arteries via the glossopharyngeal nerve (Option D): Pulmonary arteries have baroreceptors, but they are transmitted via the vagus nerve (CN X), not the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which mainly serves the carotid body and sinus.

questions.question: The nucleus of the solitary tract receives ______ sensations from the carotid body and carotid sinus primarily through _____ nerve.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) General Visceral Efferent; Glossopharyngeal nerve Explanation: The nucleus of the solitary tract receives general visceral afferent sensations from the carotid body and carotid sinus primarily through the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX). The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) carries sensory information from the carotid body (chemoreceptor) and carotid sinus (baroreceptor) to the nucleus of the solitary tract, which is involved in regulating blood pressure and respiratory responses. Nucleus of Tractus Solitarius It is a composite nucleus located in the medulla. Its functions are: General Visceral Afferent (Lower Part): Receives visceral sensations. Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX): From tonsil, pharynx, posterior tongue, carotid body, and carotid sinus. Vagus nerve (X): From the pharynx, larynx, trachea, oesophagus, and thoracic/abdominal viscera. (Option A ruled out) Special Visceral Afferent (Upper Part): Receives taste sensations. Facial nerve (VII): Anterior two-thirds of tongue and palate ( except circumvallate papillae ). (Option B ruled out) The glossopharyngeal nerve (IX): Posterior one-third of the tongue, including circumvallate papillae. Vagus nerve (X): Posterior tongue and epiglottis. Special somatic efferent; Trigeminal nerve (Option D): Special somatic efferent fibers are related to the motor innervation of certain muscles, while the trigeminal nerve (CN V) primarily carries sensory information (touch, pain) from the face and does not innervate the carotid body or sinus.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the jaw jerk reflex is false?

options.A: It is a spinal reflex initiated by tapping the jaw.
options.B: It involves the mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus as an integration centre.
options.C: The efferent pathway includes the mandibular nerve.
options.D: It is a monosynaptic reflex involving a single synapse.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) It is a spinal reflex initiated by tapping the jaw. Explanation: The jaw jerk reflex is a deep tendon reflex with supraspinal involvement which is initiated by tapping the jaw. Masseter reflex or Jaw jerk reflex It is a deep tendon reflex. The reflex is initiated by tapping the midline of the mandible, which rapidly stretches the jaw-closing muscles (masseter, temporalis, medial pterygoid). The stretch activates muscle spindle afferents, which are sensory receptors in the muscles. Afferent pathway: Muscle spindle afferents → Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve. Integration centre (Relay): Mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus. (Option B ruled out) Efferent pathway: Motor nucleus of the trigeminal nerve → Mandibular nerve. (Option C ruled out) This results in the contraction of these jaw-closing muscles and finally closure of the jaw. The jaw jerk reflex is the only significant supraspinal monosynaptic reflex due to its relay in the mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus. (Option D ruled out) The jaw jerk reflex can be tested in neurological examinations to assess the integrity of the trigeminal nerve and the brainstem pathways. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd edition, Pages 454, 455, 456, 1464e13.

questions.question: Which of the following nuclei of the trigeminal nerve is primarily responsible for proprioceptive sensations from the muscles of mastication?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Mesencephalic Nucleus Explanation: Mesencephalic Nucleus is located around the cerebral aqueduct and carries proprioceptive impulses from the muscles of mastication, facial, and extraocular muscles. The trigeminal nerve has four nuclei as follows: Main Sensory Nucleus Located in the posterior part of the pons, lateral to the motor nucleus. Continuous below with the spinal nucleus. Spinal Nucleus Extends from the pons to the second cervical segment of the spinal cord. Receives sensations of pain and temperature. (Option B ruled out) Mesencephalic Nucleus Located in the lateral part of the grey matter around the cerebral aqueduct. Receives proprioceptive impulses from muscles of mastication, facial, and extraocular muscles. Motor Nucleus Located in the pons, medial to the main sensory nucleus. Controls muscles of mastication, tensor tympani, tensor veli palatini, mylohyoid, and anterior belly of digastric. (Option D ruled out) Sensory component of Trigeminal Nuclei The motor component of Trigeminal Nuclei Carries pain, temperature, touch, pressure, and proprioception from the face. Main sensory nucleus - touch and pressure. (Option A ruled out) Spinal nucleus - pain and temperature. It extends till C2 of the spinal cord. Mesencephalic nucleus - proprioception. The motor nucleus receives inputs from both cerebral hemispheres, the reticular formation, and the red nucleus and forms a reflex arc with the mesencephalic nucleus. Supplies muscles of mastication- Temporalis Masseter Lateral pterygoid Medial pterygoid Other muscles like Tensor tympani Tensor veli palatini Mylohyoid Anterior belly of digastric

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding damage to the midline brainstem nuclei is false? tilt to the same side. inward.

options.A: Damage to the oculomotor nucleus can result in the eye looking laterally and ptosis.
options.B: Injury to the trochlear nucleus leads to difficulty in upward gaze and may cause a compensatory head
options.C: Damage to the abducens nucleus results in medial strabismus, causing the affected eye to turn
options.D: Lesion of the hypoglossal nucleus leads to weakness and atrophy of the tongue on the affected side.

questions.explanation: a compensatory head tilt to the same side. Correct Answer: B) Injury to the trochlear nucleus leads to difficulty in upward gaze and may cause a compensatory head tilt to the same side. Explanation: Damage to the trochlear nucleus causes difficulty in downward and lateral gaze, often resulting in a compensatory head tilt to the opposite side. Lesions to Medial Brainstem Nuclei- Together form the somatic motor column (GSE) Oculomotor Nucleus (CN III) : (Option A ruled out) The eye cannot move upward, downward, or inward. At rest, the eye is in a down-and-out position. The patient experiences double vision (diplopia). The upper eyelid droops (ptosis) from paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris. The pupil is widely dilated and nonreactive to light due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae and unopposed sympathetic dilator activity. Accommodation is impaired. Trochlear Nucleus (CN IV) : Difficulty in downward and lateral gaze. Patients may exhibit a compensatory head tilt to the opposite side to manage diplopia (double vision). Abducens Nucleus (CN VI) : Medial strabismus (the affected eye cannot abduct), leading to horizontal diplopia. The affected eye is often turned inward. Diplopia is also seen. (Option C ruled out) Hypoglossal Nucleus (CN XII) : Weakness of the tongue on the side of the lesion, causing atrophy and fasciculations. On protrusion, the tongue may deviate toward the affected side. (Option D ruled out) Reference: Snell’s Clinical Neuroanatomy, 8th edition, Pages 350, 351, 353 Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd edition, Page 453

questions.question: A 65 y/o patient presents with sudden dizziness, difficulty swallowing, ipsilateral loss of temperature sensation on the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk, ipsilateral ataxia, and giddiness. Which anatomical structure is responsible for the ipsilateral loss of temperature sensation on the face of this patient?

options.B: Spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve Explanation: The patient is diagnosed with Wallenberg Syndrome due to the presence of ipsilateral loss of temperature sensation on the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk, difficulty swallowing, ipsilateral ataxia, and giddiness. The spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve are responsible for the ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face, which is a hallmark feature of Wallenberg Syndrome. Wallenberg Syndrome (Lateral Medullary Syndrome) Due to stroke or infarction in the lateral part of the medulla oblongata. Mainly due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), a branch of the vertebral artery. Sometimes the vertebral artery directly supplies the lateral brainstem. Affects the dorsolateral aspect of the medulla and the inferior surface of the cerebellum. Anatomical structure affected and features: Spinothalamic tract: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation of the trunk. (Option A ruled out) Spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation of the face. Nucleus ambiguus: Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the palate, pharynx, and larynx. Inferior cerebellar peduncle and cerebellum: Ipsilateral ataxia. (Option C ruled out) Vestibular nuclei: Giddiness. (Option D ruled out)
